description.narrative: To demonstrate how Local Government Units (LGUs), with enhanced capacities, and working together with local and national partners, can plan and manage economic activities and growth in ways that meet landscape-level biodiversity conservation and sustainable use objectives in critical biogeographic regions
Population estimates of at least three critically endangered species in three demonstration sites

comment.narrative: Expected to decrease by at least 10% by end-project
No decline in populations of tamaraw in Siburan forests; Visayan hornbill in Central Panay and NNNP; and Philippine eagle in Mt. Hamiguitan

Mt Siburan in the municipality of Sablayan in the province of Mindoro Occidental is part of the habitat range of the Tamaraw that includes the adjoining Mt Aruyan Malati also in Sablayan and nearby Mt Iglit-Baco in Mindoro Oriential. Tamarraw used to be abundant throughout the island of Mindoro numbering around 10,000 in the 1900s. The most recent Tamaraw count by DENR-Tamaraw Conservation Program (TCP, April 2013) recorded 345 individuals but count stations were mostly concentrated on the southwestern portion of Mts Iglit-Baco.
The 2004 survey by Haribon Foundation in Mt Siburan reported tracks and fecal evidence of the species along the banks of Malate River. The TCP survey in Mt Aruyan-Malati estimated that around 11 tamaraw individuals were in the area. According to TCP there is no official report confirming the presence of tamaraa in Mt Siburan for some anecdotal records sometime in year 2000 regarding the presence of a Tamaraw bull in the area. The 2013 survey in Aruyan recorded ethnobiological data but failed to locate any physical evidence of the presence of the species in Mt Siburan. An ethno-biodiversity survey currently is beind conducted by Haribon, the BPP site partner to determine the number of tamaraws in Mt. Siburan. The biodiversity survey in Central Panay Mountains (CPM) in 2014 validated the presence of Visayan hornbill in CPM. The biodiversity study conducted in Northern Negros Natural Park (NNNP) counted 14 Visayan Tarictic Hornbill and 3 Rufous headed hornbill in the area. The biodiversity assessment conducted in selected sampling sites within in Mt. Hamiguitan confirmed the presence of a Philippine Eagle in Barangay Surop. The eagle is probably Cabuaya, the chick of the eagles Cabu and Aya of Mati, due to the green leg band and attached transmitter.

description.narrative: Extent of habitat fragmentation in unprotected PAs/KBAs in eight demonstration sites

comment.narrative: Expected to increase by at least10% by end-project
No net increase in fragmentation in 287,000 hectares of unprotected PAs/KBAs in eight demonstration sites

The patch analysis was used to determine the level of fragmentation in the eight (8) demonstration sites. Patch analysis deals with the threshold sizes of habitat patches beyond which they might be considered highly degraded and fragmented. This can be expressed as the proportion of habitat that is in continuous patches over, 100 square-kilometers within a particular PA/KBA. The total area of forest patch for each demonstration sites are as follows: Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area (NeCKBA): 141,840 hectares or 79.9% patch
Quirino Protected Landscapes (QPL): 93,458 hectares or 80% patch
Malampaya Sound Protected Landscapes and Seascapes (MSPLS): 23,004 hectares or 43.14% patch
Mt. Siburan: 2, 473 hectares or 59.71% patch
Mt. Hamiguitan: 16,900 or 76.24% patch
Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area (LMKBA): 12,139 hectares or 7.98% patch
Central Panay Mountains (CPM): 76,103 hectares or 99.9%
Northern Negros Natural Park (NNNP): 27,690 hectares or 99.97%

description.narrative: Number of hectares in production landscapes/ waterscapes under sustainable management

comment.narrative: No increase during the period

At least additional 10,000 hectares under sustainable management but not yet certified At least additional 800 hectares and 8 production systems under certified production practices that meet sustainability and biodiversity standards

A total of 128,138 hectares have been identified and classified/zoned as sustainable use management areas. The classification/zonation of these areas was part of the mainstreaming of biodiversity in the local land use plans of the LGUs in the eight demonstration sites. The sustainable use management areas shall be developed and managed to improve the land productivity to support agricultural production and agri-based livelihood opportunities through sustainable upland management strategies and land and water use conservation. These sustainable use management areas coverage are as follows: Quirino (Nagtipunan and Maddela):31,124 hectares
Cagayan: 60,936 hectares Calatrava, Negros Occidental: 2,362 hectares
Taytay, Palawan: 33,716 hectares. The additional 10,000 hectares that will be subject to certification will be specified from these areas delineated as sustainable use management zones. To date, about 1,209 hectares in the eight project sites were assessed and documented as potential sites of farm areas practicing biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices. These areas upon initial assessment meet the standards of biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices. Further assessment and documentation of the areas will be done upon once DENR and DA approve the policy, standards, and certifications schemes for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices is obtained from DENR and DA. The standards for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices have been drafted and would be finalized following approval of the Joint Administrative Order of DA and DENR on the promotion of BD-friendly agricultural practices in PAs and KBAs and wider agricultural landscape is issued. Subsequently, the BPP-PMU will discuss with DA Team strategies to meet the target of at least 800 hectares and 8 production systems under certified production practices that meet sustainability and biodiversity standards.

description.narrative: National-level systems, policies, tools and capacities are in place to support LGU-level biodiversity conservation efforts
Agencies with policies and associated capacity to conduct biodiversity impact assessment of sectoral policies and plans

comment.narrative: None
DA and DENR are routinely conducting biodiversity impact assessments of sectoral policies and plans by year 4.

The applicability of biodiversity impact assessments using the biodiversity-focused Strategic Environment Assessment (BDSEA) process will be pilot-tested to DENR-Biodiversity Management Bureaus (BMB) plans, policies and programs. The BDSEA has gone through several consultations with the Technical Review Committee of BMB. This was also presented and discussed with key National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA) officers and staff for possible issuance of an Executive Order for adoption and government-wide use of BDSEA. The draft Department Administrative Order (DAO) on BDSEA was presented and discussed with the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) Policy Technical Working Group (PTWG). The DENR PTWG recommended for the issuance of a Memorandum Circular (MC) in lieu of the proposed DAO for the adoption of the BDSEA Manual of Procedures (MoP) within the DENR. The MoP for BDSEA was reviewed by the BMB Senior Staff and Technical Review Committee. Pending the approval of the MC for the application of the MoP, the BMB-review committee suggested to have a Technical Bulletin to have an enabling document to apply the manual at the BPP sites. The Technical Bulletin was prepared and for signature of BMB Director.

description.narrative: Programmes and policies to support biodiversity friendly agricultural production in critical landscapes

comment.narrative: No agrobiodiversity programs in AFMA plan National Action Plan for Sustainable Land management (NAP-SLM) do not include agrobiodiversity projects in buffer zones of PAs and KBAs Standards and certification schemes limited to organic agricultural production Activities to promote conservation and utilization of indigenous crops

Updated AFMA Plan incorporates agrobiodiversity programs. Revised NAP-SLM includes agrobiodiversity projects in buffer zones of PAs or KBAs. Standards and certification system for biodiversity friendly production systems in place Policy and program developed in DA to promote conservation and utilization of indigenous crops

The Department of Agriculture (DA) has proposed that instead of updating the AFMA plan, a Joint Administrative Order be promulgated because the updating of the AFMA Plan is not being done on a yearly basis. Furthermore, the AFMA covers the wider agricultural landscapes that covers various stakeholders while the area of focus for mainstreaming biodiversity will be within and around the Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas. The request was reflected in a DA letter to the DENR dated July 2014. The DA-DENR Joint Administrative Order: Mainstreaming Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices In and Around Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas and Promoting the Same in Wider Agricultural Landscapes is subject to parallel review of DENR Policy Technical Working Group (PTWG) and DA Policy Review Committee. The draft National Action Plan for Sustainable Land Management (NAP-SLM) has been prepared which provides for robust discussion on biodiversity. The concern on biodiversity is part of the Strategic Objective 2 of NAP-SLM: To regenerate and rehabilitate watershed landscapes and their resources for ecosystem services enhancement. The NAP-SLM also incorporates two (2) sub-programs of the Thematic Program 3: Watershed Landscape Management and Rehabilitation includes biodiversity as follows: 1) Sustainable management of forest resources; and 2) Promotion of SLM for forest resources conservation and management. It also include the listings of completed and ongoing projects on biodiversity in buffer zones of Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas. The said draft NAP-SLM is being reviewed by Department of Agriculture and targeted for approval by end of 2015. Drafted the Philippine National Standard for Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices. This standard describes the requirements for Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices for the production of agricultural and fishery commodities [in and around PAs and KBAs]. Likewise, this standard provides a mechanism to define Biodiversity-Friendly Agricultural Practices and when complied with, it also enables producers to label their product accordingly. However, the standard does not cover procedures for verification, such as inspection or certification of products. Through the ITPGRFA project, the protocols for on-farm conservation of traditional varieties will be developed. The basis for this protocol will be the available technical information in scientific literature as well as practices applicable to the community setting. Other possible reference in drafting the said protocol are the good agricultural production and conservation practices which is biodiversity friendly observed during field studies and Community Field School. To date, as a result of the study conducted by ITPGRFA project, the information on the incentives for promotion of conservation as a result of the key informant interviews with producers, market actors, and institutional actors showed minimal incentives for promotion of traditional rice and root crops. The elements of the draft strategic action plan (SAP) for the conservation and sustainable use of traditional varieties of rice, yam, taro and sweet potato were identified through the preparatory phase, stakeholder analysis and field studies in the six pilot barangays in the four provinces covered by the ITPGRFA project. The elements of the SAP were identified and will be the basis of the draft that will be prepared.

description.narrative: Systems and procedures for implementation of new regulations of trade in wild plant and animal resources

comment.narrative: Department Order issued
System established for surveillance, monitoring, and mapping the sources of illegally traded wild plants and animals

The system being established for surveillance, monitoring, and mapping the sources of illegally traded wild plants and animals is in a form of partnerships with various national government agencies that are have mandates, capabilities and procedures in detecting, preventing and restricting illegal trade and transport of wildlife. The DENR together with the following agencies: Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), Department of Agriculture-Bureau of Animal Industry (DA-BAI), Department of Agriculture-Bureau of Plant Industry (DA-BPI), Department of Trade and Industry, Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board (LTRFB), Land Transportation Office (LTO), Maritime Industry Authority (MIA), Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines (CAAB), Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB), Philippine Coast Guard (PCG), Philippine Ports Authority (PPA), Light Rail Transit Authority (LRTA), Philippine National Railways (PNR), Philippine National Police (PNP), National Bureau of Investigation (NBI), Office for Transportation Security (OTS), Bureau of Customs (BoC), and National Prosecution Service (NPS) is in the process of creating an Inter-agency Committee. Initial meetings have been carried out to fine tune the Memorandum of Agreement (MoA) providing for, among other things, the creation of the inter-agency committee and specifying the responsibilities of partner agencies. The BMB and BPP-PMU successfully convened a consultation meeting with these agencies last April 7, 2015 review the final draft of the MoA. The final draft of the MoA is now being refined to incorporate the inputs solicited during this meeting.

description.narrative: Policies to encourage investments in biodiversity friendly business

comment.narrative: None
Policy in place at DTI Priority biodiversity business identified in DTI policy documents.

Incorporated the biodiversity friendly business/enterprise concept in the Memorandum Circular No. 2015- 01 General Policies and Specific Guidelines to Implement the Investment Priorities Plan (IPP) 2014 2016 under the Part XII. Support to Environmental Protection and Conservation to encourage registered enterprises to protect and conserve biodiversity in their respective area and/or activities and promote biodiversity-friendly businesses/enterprises. Revised the Joint Administrative Order of Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), Department of Tourism (DOT), and Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) on Adopting Biodiversity-Friendly Business and Enterprise Framework and Criteria as well as the Framework and Criteria for Assessing Biodiversity-Friendly Business to incorporate comments and concerns of the BMB Technical Review Committee and provided clearer description of the industry categories as well as indicators and criteria.

A Knowledge Management System (KMS) established by BPP at BMB is a web-based type database and information source, this can be accessed at www.philbiodiversitypartnerships.com.

comment.narrative: Nil

description.narrative: LGUs in critical biogeographic regions with local regulations and capacity to implement policies on wildlife trade

comment.narrative: Nil

10 LGUs with local Ordinances to support regulation of local endemics 10 LGUs with staff trained on policies and procedures governing wildlife trade Local coordinating bodies established with DENR, wildlife enforcement agents and volunteers to strengthen regulation of wildlife trade

1 LGU (Calatrava) with local ordinances (Local Environment Code) to support regulation of local endemics. Ongoing preparation of Baggao, Cagayan LEC. Two (2) LGUs (Calatrava in NNNP and Baggao in NeCKBA) have already conducted workshops for the preparation of Local Environment Code (LEC) that provide detail on regulation of local endemics under the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act (Republic Act No. 9147) while a LEC orientation was conducted for the remaining five (5) LGUs within NeCKBA. Two (2) LGUs (Alegria, Surigao Del Norte and Santiago, Agusan Del Norte ) provided their existing Local Environment Code to Lake Mainit BPP team for assessment and further enhancement to include details on regulation of local endemics. 25 LGUs with staff trained on policies and procedures governing wildlife trade. description.narrative: LGUs with regulatory structures and incentive systems to encourage the development of biodiversity-friendly businesses, including investor codes of conduct

comment.narrative: Nil
10 LGUs in project sites with regulatory structures, incentive systems, investor codes of conduct and programs and budgets promoting BD-friendly business.

7 out of 10 target LGUs in project sites passed the Local Investment and Incentive Code (LIIC). The LIIC is a document that articulates the local governments investment policies and programs, Investments Priority Areas (IPAs), and local incentives (fiscal and non-fiscal) available to domestic and foreign investors, and the mechanics for availing them. The LIIC is an instrument for attracting, retaining, expanding and diversifying investments in the local economy, is supportive of local, regional and national economic development, and is developed through a multi-stakeholder process. While ongoing technical assistance on LIIC formulation is being done in Taytay, San Vicente, Governor Genoroso and Mati City. The following LGUs passed LIIC as ordinance:
Quirino Protected Landscapes
Saguday
Diffun Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area (NeCKBA)
Sta. Teresita
Buguey
Lal-lo Mt. Siburan
Sablayan Mt.Hamiguitan
San Isidro

description.narrative: Mechanisms and capacities for intra LGU knowledge sharing on mainstreaming biodiversity

comment.narrative: Mechanisms exist for intra LGU sharing on environment programs and performance but not on biodiversity

Mechanism and network established to regularly share lessons on mainstreaming biodiversity New national policy proposals formulated/approved based on lessons from LGUs/project sites Improved capacity by LGUs to advocate improved policies

Strengthened the Local Project Site Committee for inter-Local Government Unit sharing of best practices. Ongoing organization of Biodiversity Network (Bd-Net), a sustainability platform for advocacy/information, education and communication and capacity building activities across stakeholders. The network will also ensure sustained efforts in terms of knowledge exchange and sharing. As response to the Midterm Evaluators recommendation, the BMB and BPP-PMU will convene a round table discussion series as part of the knowledge sharing process /event series. This will serve as a culmination activity for the project to present and share significant results and lessons learned and draw up new policy program and program proposals. The project will provide assistance in the formulation of improved templates for key LGU policies and ordinances based on the project experience in mainstreaming, biodiversity friendly agriculture practices and business as well as wildlife trade.

description.narrative: Systems, policies, tools and capacities for landscape-level biodiversity conservation and sustainable development are applied at eight pilot sites covering at least 700,000 hectares across five critical biogeographic regions (Luzon, Palawan, Negros-Panay, Mindoro, Mindanao).
LGU development plans at project sites complying with SEA approach, as well as landscape level natural resources management

comment.narrative: LGUs do not apply SEAs in local development planning PA management plans and FLUPs not integrated in CLUPs

At least 20% of LGUs in the project sites apply SEA in their development planning. At least 20% of LGUs in the project sites integrate biodiversity conservation zoning (PA or KBA zoning) in their CLUP.

As mentioned in Outcome 2, about 12% of the total LGUs covered by the project were given Orientation Training on simplified BDSEA. Orientation will still be done to other LGUs. As per recommendation of the Midterm Evaluators and subject to GEF approval, instead of 8 LGUs (at least 20% of LGUs) focal attention shall be provided to at least two (2) LGUs. Accordingly, this proposal will allow the BPP-PMU to provide more time in fine-tuning delivery systems; documentation of lessons learned; and facilitating sharing and reflection among early practitioners of SEA. The PMU will focus on Training and Coaching in the use of the simplified BDSEA for LGUs this 3rd and 4th quarter of 2015. 56% of LGUs in the project sites integrate biodiversity conservation zoning (PA or KBA zoning) in their CLUP. Update on the mainstreaming work: CLUPs of LGUs in Quirino Protected Landscape and Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area were already approved

CLUP of Calatrava is for final writing
CLUP of Silay is under Options formulation
CLUP of Sebaste is at the level of Land Use policy formulation and sectoral studies

description.narrative: Inter LGU cooperation in planning and regulation of natural resource use

comment.narrative: Municipal and City LGUs plan separately and do not coordinate and harmonize their plans. Provincial Land Use Committees oversee and approves municipal and city land use plans. LGUs within PAs or KBAs do not jointly adopt any economic PES instruments

At least two transboundary conservation areas established LGUs in the project sites (at least 3 jointly managed landscapes) harmonize their development plans for natural resource use in biodiversity landscapes that cut across their administrative boundaries. LGUs in the project sites sharing PA or KBA areas jointly adopt resource planning tools such as FLUP, ICRMP, ecological zoning. At least 3 Provincial CLUPs in the project sites adopt the planning tools for biodiversity conservation. PES instrument developed and tested in at least one biodiversity landscape.

Two (2) Transboundary Conservation Areas will be established in Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area (NECKBA) covering six (6) LGUs and Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area (LMKBA) covering eight (4) LGUs each in Agusan and Surigao Del Norte. Protected Area Management Plan (PAMP) for Quirino Protected Landscape (QPL) is being enhanced and finalized. The PAMP for Northern Negros Natural Park (NNNP) was enhanced. Taytay and San Vicente LGUs in Malampaya Sound Protected Landscapes jointly adopt the Forest Land Use Plan (FLUP), ICRMP and Environmental Critical Area Network (ECAN) Framework planning. ECAN Framework planning was initiated by Palawan Council for Sustainable Development (PCSD). Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES) instruments on Watershed Management and Water Systems were developed and pilot-tested in Quirino Protected Landscapes (QPL).

description.narrative: New conservation areas established

comment.narrative: s
Three new conservation areas established covering 15 LGUs

Delineated 2 (two) new conservation areas as Local Conservation Areas in Tubod and Mainit, Surigao Del Norte. Drafted ordinance declaring the municipalities of Alegria and Kitcharao as Local Conservation Areas. 1 LGU (Lambunao) in Central Panay Mountains approved the Resolution declaring 2,318.42 hectares as Critical Habitat this aim to conserve and protect the wildlife species within, regulate the collection and trade of wildlife, address the threats and effectively manage. 1 LGU (Sebaste) in Central Panay Mountains drafted an Ordinance Providing for the Establishment of a Critical Habitat (2,567hectares) in the Municipality of Sebaste, Province of Antique defining the Area of Coverage, Creating Institutional Management Mechanisms, Defining its Powers and Functions and for Other Purposes

description.narrative: Farmers adopting biodiversity friendly practices

comment.narrative: No increase over project period
At least 5,000 farmers adopting biodiversity friendly agricultural practices Additional 2,000 farmers and producers meeting certification standards

About two (2) hectares of demonstration farm for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices was established in Sitio Mahucdam, Bgy. Kapayaan, Tubod, Surigao Norte. The project provided assistance in the establishment of a demonstration farm covering around 2.17 hectares in Sitio Managaksak, Brgy. Sta. Cruz, Murcia, Negros Occidental. Same assistance was provided to Brgy. Eden, Cabarroguis, Quirino in the establishment of 22. 9 hectares of demonstration farms following the biodiversity-friendly principles. Based on assessment using the biodiversity-friendly agricultural practices framework and principles, about 893 farmers are practicing biodiversity-friendly agricultural practices. Completed profiles of additional model sites for biodiversity-friendly agriculture practices. Conducted initial suitability assessment of the proposed model/demonstration farm site in MSPLS in Palawan and in Mt. Siburan in Sablayan, Mindoro Occidental. The standards for biodiversity-friendly agricultural practices is still being finalized.

description.narrative: Pressures from overharvesting of wild resources

comment.narrative: Expected to increase over total area of KBAs/PAs in project sites by 10% each year
Pressure reduced in PAs totaling at least 260,000 hectares No net reduction in population of key species in selected sites (e.g., hornbill, Philippine eagle, etc.)

The policy on the guidelines for the harmonized implementation of regulations on the domestic trade in wildlife is still under review of the policy review committee of DENR. The protection and rehabilitation of remaining forests and wildlife habitats were included in the CLUPs and CDPs of LGUs that participated in the BD mainstreaming work. To reduced the pressure in Protected Areas totaling at least 260,000 hectares, the Local Government Units were encouraged to have an enhanced Local Environment Code (LEC) that elaborate the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act (Republic Act No. 9147) which states that LGUs shall initiate conservation measures for endemic species in their areas. To date, the status of LEC preparations are as follows: 1 LGU (Calatrava) with local ordinances (Local Environment Code) to support regulation of local endemics. Ongoing preparation of Baggao, Cagayan LEC. Two (2) LGUs (Calatrava in NNNP and Baggao in NeCKBA) have already conducted workshops for the preparation of Local Environment Code (LEC) that provide detail on regulation of local endemics under the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act (Republic Act No. 9147) while a LEC orientation was conducted for the remaining five (5) LGUs within NeCKBA. Two (2) LGUs (Alegria, Surigao Del Norte and Santiago, Agusan Del Norte ) provided their existing Local Environment Code to Lake Mainit BPP team for assessment and further enhancement to include details on regulation of local endemics. Completed the Biodiversity Assessments in the eight (8) sites, biodiversity monitoring will be done in 2016.

description.narrative: Private investments in biodiversity friendly business in selected project sites

comment.narrative: Nil
At least four businesses engaged in biodiversity-friendly enterprises in project sites by year 5. At least four producer groups in PAs/KBAs adhere to LGU investor codes of conduct

Based on the assessment done using the biodiversity-friendly business/enterprise framework and assessment tool, the following enterprises have potential for scale-up: Bakong Enterprise
Marine products in Buguey, Cagayan
Quirino Ginger Tea, Bamboo, Coffee, Banana and Cornstarch
Pandan leaves and bamboo small furnitures in Malampaya
Souvenir items production (made of nito, nipay seeds and tiger grass)
Organic vegetables in Gawahon
Almaciga resin tapping in Mt. Hamiguitan Status to date: Ongoing ecological and feasibility study for the bakong enterprise
Ongoing feasibility study for marine products in Buguey, Cagayan
Ongoing formulation of Cooperative systems and procedures for the Malampaya Pancol Multipurpose Cooperative (MPMC)
Memorandum of Agreement (MoA) signed with Mati City for the provision of funds to support expansion of almaciga resin production. To institutionalize and sustain support to the identified biodiversity-friendly business in the project sites, various agreements with the private sectors, peoples organizations and local consolidators are being finalized, the status are as follows:
Memoranda of Understanding between private sectors and Biodiversity Management Bureau are for signing, the private sectors are as follows: Association of Negros Producers and Freshstart Organics in Negros Occidental; Antique Development Foundation in CPM.
Tripartite MoU between Quirino Provincial Local Government Units (QPLGU), Philippine Coffee Alliance, Inc. and (PCAI) Mataga-ay Sustainable Resources Development and Conservation Association (MASREDECA) for signing.
Tripartite Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between DENR through BMB, QPLGU and Bote Central for signing.

description.narrative: Communities receiving incentives for shifting to sustainable practices

comment.narrative: Nil

Conservation agreements in place with at least two community groups in CPM and NNNP PES schemes negotiated with two more community groups in other sites in PPLS and NNNP 10 communities engaged in sustainable livelihoods

The transboundary planning in CPM was deferred due to lack of interest of the LGUs to pursue the said planning. The Project Management Unit (PMU) and Local Responsible Partner tried to convene for the Orientation Workshop on Transboundary Planning for Central Panay Mountains (CPM) the Provinces of Iloilo, Antique, Aklan and Capiz but only the Province of Iloilo was receptive, thus, the Orientation Workshop was pursued last July 17-18, 2014 for Iloilo, however, the succeeding workshops were not convened due to lack of interest and unavailability of the respective sectoral representatives to participate. The conservation agreements in CPM however, is covered in the Critical Habitat Declaration and Management Plan for instance, goal number 3, in the proposed Critical Habitat Management Plan for Lambunao elaborate the sustainably manage human activities through community-based resource management. In addition, Conservation Agreement (CAs) are being done in Mt. Hamiguitan in partnerships with the existing projects of Philippine Eagle Foundation. The project provided
complementary support to the community-based management of the Philippine Eagle Sanctuary by providing
funds for the pilot-testing of a Public-Private-Community (PPC) partnership through
Conservation Agreements (CAs). This
aims to provide forms of conservation
incentives to local communities who act
as managers of biodiversity areas and
have shown clear conservation outcomes
out of their management work. In return, the communities pledged to do
their share in conservation through
reforestation in their own farm lots. PES schemes in NNNP in partnership with the Provincial Environment and Management Office (PEMO) will still be identified. Around nine (9) peoples organizations /communities are engaging in biodiversity-friendly livelihoods. These are as follows:
1. MASREDECA (Mataga-ay Sustainable Resources Development and Conservation Association) in QPL
2. MPMC (Malampaya Pancol Multipurpose Cooperative) in MSPLS
3. SIKAP (Samahang Inaasahan ng mga Katutubo sa Alimanguan, Palawan) in MSPLS
4. PAFISFA (Patag Farmers Integrated Social Foresty Association) in NNNP
5. VISFA (Victorias Integrated Social Forestry Association) in NNNP
6. TIGMAMUGON (Tigbobolo Mangunguma, Mangingisda,Mamumugon) Association/ Tigbobolo Bamboocraft Association, Brgy. Tigbobolo, Culasi, Antique in CPM
7. SJVPA (Multipurpose Cooperative in Santiago, San Jose Producers Association in Mainit, Lake Mainit KBA
8. EPATLEA (Eco-Park Agri-Tourism Livelihood Enterprise Association n Kitcharao, Lake Mainit KBA
9. LATAGG (Lumad Almaciga Tappers Association of Gov. Generoso) in Mt. Hamiguitan

description.narrative: Data and knowledge management systems to support local initiatives

comment.narrative: Some LGUs have isolated data and knowledge management systems but not linked to national system Insufficient data to adequately monitor status and trends in biodiversity and impacts of development programs

Rapid resource assessments completed/updated in eight project sites Population estimates of critically endangered species in eight sites determined Monitoring system in place to determine progress in meeting conservation plan objectives, linked to knowledge management system Increased public awareness and positive support to conservation efforts among local stakeholders LGU level data and knowledge management system enhanced LGU staff trained in use of data and knowledge management system LGUs able to access and share data and information in national system

Rapid resource assessments in the eight sites were completed and ecological profiles were updated. Population estimates as of (2013-2014) of the critically endangered species of both fauna and flora in the eight sites are as follows: Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area
Fauna:
Oriolus isabellae (Isabela Oriole): 3 ind. Flora:
Hopea cagayanensis (Narek): 18 ind.
Shorea polysperma (Taguile): 94 ind
Shorea contorta (White lauan): 66 ind
Shorea negrosensis (Red Lauan): 82 ind
Parashorea malaanonan (Bagtikan): 21 ind.
Shorea palosapis (Mayapis): 190 ind.
Shorea astylosa (Yakal): 42 ind.
Hopea malibato (Yakal-kaliot): 48 ind.
Shorea guiso (Guijo): 14 ind.
Dipterocarpus grandiflorus (Apitong): 8 ind.
Anisopthera thurifera (Palosapis): 19 ind.
Shorea malibato (Yakal malibato): 4 ind.
Hopea acuminata (Mangachapui): 1 ind.
Shorea assamica (Mangasinoro): 2 ind.
Tristaniopsis decorticata (Malabayabas): 6 ind.
Toona calantas (Kalantas): 2 ind. Quirino Protected Landscapes Fauna:
Oriolus isabellae (Isabela Oriole) Pithecophaga jefferyi (Philippine Eagle)
No recorded sightings as of biodiversity assessment survey conducted last 2013-2014. Flora:
Dipterocarpus gracilis (Panau)
Dipterocarpus grandiflorus (Apitong)
Dipterocarpus hasselti
Dipterocarpus kunstleri
Dipterocarpus validus (Hagakhak)
Hopea acuminata (Mangachapui)
Shorea contorta (White lauan)
Shorea guiso (Guijo)
Shorea negrosensis (Red Lauan)
Shorea palosapis (Mayapis)
Shorea polysperma (Taguile) Mt. Siburan Fauna:
Centropus steerii (Black-hooded Coucal): 85 ind.
Gallicolumba platenae (Mindoro Bleeding Heart): 1 ind.
Cacatua haematuropygia (Philippine Cockatoo): no sightings as of survey conducted
Bubalus mindorensis (Tamaraw): presence/count to be validated through enthno-biosurvey. Malampaya Sound Protected Landscape and Seascape: Based on the survey conducted on the Palawan forest turtle in So. Maubog, Bgy. Alacalian, Taytay, Palawan, 28 Palawan forest turtle were captured. Out of 28 individuals, there are 4 males, 4 females and 20 are juvenile whereby the sexual characteristic is not yet differentiated. The baseline photo identification survey of the critically endangered Irrawaddy Dolphin (Orcaella brevirostris) using Darwin software revealed that there are 47 individuals within Malampaya Sound through photo identification based on their dorsal fin. Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area
Based on the biodiversity assessment survey conducted in the municipalities covering the Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area, two (2) Tarictic Hornbill (Penelopides panini ) were sighted in Jabonga, Agusan del Norte. The presence of Manggachapui or dalingdingan (Hopea acuminata), one of the critically endangered species of flora are found in Jabonga, Santiago, Kitcharao. While the Rafflesia mixta was found in Mainit, Surigao del Norte. A total of 7 Silvery Kingfisher (Alcedo argentata) , six (6) White-collared Fruit Bat (Megaerops wetmorei ), 21 Mindanao Horned Frog (Megophrys stejnegeri), and Mangkuno (Xantostemon verdugonianus) classified as vulnerable were recorded within Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area, aside from these the almaciga (Agathis philippinensis), an endangered species were also found in Tubod, Surigao del Norte. Drafted the Framework for the local biodiversity M&E System (LBMES). The design and manual for local biodiversity M&E System (LBMES) for LGUs, report on the pilot-testing of the LBMES and Implementation Plan and enabling document for the installation and operationalization of the LBMES within DILG and the LGUs still ongoing.
Continous advocacy and awareness activities in various forms e.g. exhibits, knowledge products, paper presentations (on preliminary results of biodiversity-friendly business/enterprise in Convention on Biological Diversity Side Event in Pyeongchang Korea and Asean Social Forestry Network Conference for ASEAN Economic Community in Inle Lake, Shan State, Myanmar).

description.narrative: Community-managed landscapes and seascapes explicitly integrate biodiversity conservation objectives
Number of ha under improved community mainstreamed? management within PLS, reducing threats to BD from slash and burn farming; over-harvesting of timber, and destructive fishing.

None yet. The project has just approved its first set of proposals. The first proposals have big potential for starting out new landscapes. At this point, proposals are being developed using the landscape strategy. The project has been in constant dialogue with local CSOs. So far, five potential landscapes have been identified: (1) Northern Samar, connecting the Samar Island National Park and the BiRi LaRosa Protected Seascape; (3) the stretch of forests, ancestral domains and coastal areas of San Luis up to Maria Aurora in Aurora Province; (3) the environs of the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park, which can serve as its buffer zone; (4) the unprotected Victoria-Anepaan Mountain Range in southern Palawan; and (5) the Mt. Caraballo-Mt. Palali ranges, which connects Sierra Madre and Cordillera mountain ranges. Site-based consultations and project developments are in various stages.

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Availability of an incentive mechanism for private sector in Weather Index-based Insurance (WIBI) Provision 2. Percent of target population covered by Weather Index-based Insurance (WIBI) mechanism 3. Percent of community groups in target areas trained in climate change risk reduction

comment.narrative: 1. No available incentive mechanism for private sector in Weather Index-based Insurance (WIBI) Provision [2014] 2. 0% [2014] 3. 0% [2014]

description.narrative: Poverty reduction by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable agriculture-based rural communities in Mindanao through climate risk transfer mechanisms and productivity enhancement measures

% of population covered by weather index-based insurance mechanism
Improved damage rate in rice farming

comment.narrative: No families are currently covered by WIBI in the project target sites Average damage rate from 30-year history for rice is 22-26% but the damage rate from target population will be established during the inception phase of the project.

At least 3,000 families in target villages are covered by WIBI Beneficiary farmers demonstrate 20% damage rate (i.e. 2-6% lower than average) during the normal year (i.e. when WIBI pay-outs are not made)

For the first batch of beneficiaries covering the June 2015 rice cropping season, project will be providing WIBI to 251 farmers by 30 June 2015 or 12.55% of the total. For this initial reporting period, indicator on reduced damage rate in rice farming cannot be measured at this time.

description.narrative: Regulatory and fiscal incentive structures adjusted to stimulate private sector engagement in climate risk reduction and transfer for agriculture-based rural households.
Availability of an incentive mechanism for private sector in WIBI provision PCICs readiness in expanding WIBI to new crops beyond rice and corn

comment.narrative: Currently there is no incentive mechanism in place to stimulate private sector engagement in WIBI provision PCIC is not ready for designing a new WIBI contract beyond rice and corn

The application of AGFP adjusted/expanded for FSPs to avail preferential guarantee coverage Preliminary assessments for covering new crops under WIBI are complete and PCIC is ready to start pilot testing

Board approval of amended Implementing Rules and Regulations of the Agricultural Guarantee Fund Pool (AGFP) has been obtained in April 2015; in the process of endorsement to the Secretary of the Department of Agriculture for final approval. AGFP Special Orders for accredited FSPs to avail of preferential guarantee coverage have been drafted. The Project will support the Agricultural Credit Policy Council and the AGFP to help raise awareness of their partner FSPs on the preferential guarantee coverage availment and benefits. Preliminary discussions among relevant agencies on expanding WIBI to new crops beyond rice have been initiated - corn and other high value crops such as coconut with available rainfall correlation studies will be further studied for further refinement and demonstration.

description.narrative: Weather Index-based Integrated Financial Package customized and applied to strengthen climate resilience in the agriculture sector in Mindanao
% of population covered by weather index-based insurance mechanism [AMAT 1.2.2]

comment.narrative: No families are currently covered by WIBI in the project target sites
At least 3,000 families in target villages are covered by WIBI [The number of female-headed households as well as gender disaggregated performance, where possible, will be reported]
For the first batch of beneficiaries covering the June 2015 rice cropping season, project will be providing WIBI to 251 farmers by 30 June 2015 or 12.55% of the total target.

description.narrative: Farmers and producers organizations able to analyze climate risk, and develop and implement adaptation practices to enhance productivity in agriculture
Number of community groups trained in climate change risk reduction [AMAT 2.3.1.2]

comment.narrative: There has not been barangay-level vulnerability assessments to date

At least 30 barangays are aware of both slow and sudden climate risks and of response measures At least 600 farmers and 20 farmers associations have been trained on resilient agriculture techniques [Gender-disaggregated target will be determined during the inception phase of the project]

The first batch of 251 farmers from 49 barangays in Regions X and XI received training on climate change basics and good agricultural practices from concerned government agencies, as part of their enrollment into the WIBI program.

activity-description.narrative: The overall objective of this Project is to optimize the contribution of migration in regional and local development in Western Visayas.
